Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop rigorously understood, highly efficient and accurate computational tools (algorithms and their software implementation, based on a solid theoretical foundation) for simulating the motion of networks of surfaces under geometric motions such as motion by weighted mean curvature and motion by surface diffusion. The approach is based on a new, variational formulation of threshold dynamics (also known as diffusion generated motion) of Merriman, Bence, and Osher that makes it possible to correctly extend the original algorithm to e.g. weighted mean curvature flow of multiple phases with unequal and anisotropic surface tensions.

The geometric motions that will be studied in this project play a central role in materials science, where they describe the microstructural evolution of polycrystalline materials under common industrial processes such as annealing (heat treatment). Polycrystalline materials are very common: most metals and ceramics belong to this category. They are composed of tiny single-crystal pieces, known as grains, that are joined together along their faces. The physical properties of these materials, such as conductivity and yield strength, depend intimately on their microstructure (the shapes and sizes of the grains that make up the material). This project will advance our ability to simulate how the microstructure of these materials change, which is important for computational design of materials, where computer simulations rather than costly experiments would identify the most favorable processing parameters for achieving desired characteristics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project developed new algorithms for simulating the motion of interfaces -- curves in the plane or surfaces in space -- under geometric motions such as motion by mean curvature. This type of motion arises in a variety of applications, most notably in materials science where it describes the evolution of microstructure in polycrystalline materials during heat treatment. Such materials include most metals and ceramics. They are composed of tiny crystallites, called grains, that are stuck together. The shapes and sizes of the grains influence physical characteristics of the material, such as its strength and conductivity. Motion by mean curvaure describes how the boundaries between the grains (which form a network of surfaces in the material) change when the material is heated.

Intellectual merit: Threshold dynamics is a well known and elegant algorithm for simulating motion by mean curvature of networks of interfaces. It is efficient enough to allow large scale computer simulations that are of interest e.g. to materials scientists. However, until recently, it only applied to networks in which the motion of the interfaces are isotropic. In applications, it is also of interest to allow the interfaces to move by anisotropic versions of this motion, for example due to preferred directions that crystal structures of many materials dictate. This project developed the extension of threshold dynamics to motion by weighted (anisotropic) mean curvature. For example, the more elaborate models  for grain boundary motion incorporating anisotropy in the materials science literature prescribe physical quantiites known as surface tension and mobility to each interface in the network. One of the findings of this project is a method to incorporate (bake) into the threshold dynamics scheme the desired anisotropic surface tension and anisotropic mobility of each interface in the network.

Broader impact: The project's outcome is an algorithm that can be used in large scale simulations of certain microstructure evolution models well known to materials scientists. Such simulations are often employed to study how common processes such as annealing may change the internal structure and, consequently, the physical properties of the material. The project contributed efficient new computational tools for this type of study. In addition, it supported the Ph.D. thesis research of multiple graduate students. Two have already received their Ph.D.s and moved on to postdoctoral positions. It also provided for summer research experience of several undergraduate students majoring in mathematics.
